eadid.publicid: -//David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library//TEXT (US::NcD::John Houstoun papers, 1773-1793 //EN

titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the John Houstoun papers, 1773-1793
titlestmt.author: Processed by: Rubenstein Staff; EAD finding aid derived from MARC record using marc2ead_sectionA.xsl

profiledesc.creation: Finding aid derived from MARC record via marc2ead_sectionA.xsl, November 2021

repository.label: Repository
repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University

did.abstract: Papers include an order for the defense of Richmond County; a letter, 1784, from John Habersham discussing negotiations with Indian representatives concerning land purchases, and an incident between Georgia residents and Indians; a statement of dissent from the Boundary Commission concerning the boundary dispute between South Carolina and Georgia; a petition to adjourn court to allow jurors to put down an Indian attack, and miscellaneous land grants, indentures, and summonses.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

prefercite.p: John Houstoun Papers, 1773-1793, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

processinfo.p: This finding aid was derived from a MARC record using a crosswalk defined in marc2ead_sectionA.xsl. The finding aid was generated as part of a larger project to digitize several thousand small collections housed in Section A, November 2021.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: John Houstoun was governor of Georgia and a jurist, from Savannah.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: Papers include an order for the defense of Richmond County; a letter, 1784, from John Habersham discussing negotiations with Indian representatives concerning land purchases, and an incident between Georgia residents and Indians; a statement of dissent from the Boundary Commission concerning the boundary dispute between South Carolina and Georgia; a petition to adjourn court to allow jurors to put down an Indian attack, and miscellaneous land grants, indentures, and summonses.
